awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Toward a General Theory of Information Transfer via Timing
awd_abstract_narration:
Information theory, communication theory, and statistical signal 
processing have proven spectacularly successful as innovation engines 
for communication, data compression, and information processing 
technologies. Although in principle these theories are quite general, 
in practice they are most useful for a particular family of models, 
such as discrete Markov sources and channels with additive 
Gaussian noise. Although this family is quite rich and encompasses 
many practical technologies, there are several important scenarios that
fall outside of these models. In particular, the timing of discrete events is 
the modality of interest in many applications, such as neuroscience
and certain problems in network security, and this modality does 
not fit neatly into the standard classes. This research involves
extending information theory, communication theory, and statistical signal
processing to develop a general theory of information transfer via timing. 

The first phase of this research involves solving several concrete
problems involving information transfer via timing, such as the
secrecy capacity of timing channels and how to minimize information
transfer via timing side channels in both wireless and wireline
networks. The second phase involves interconnecting these disparate
problems to form a general theory of information transfer via timing.
By elevating the role of timing in information transfer,
this research better positions the fields of information theory,
communication theory, and statistical signal processing to
impact allied fields such as networking, neuroscience, and 
operations research, where timing and delay are of fundamental
importance. This impact is facilitated through special topics 
courses and invited sessions at conferences, both of which are 
designed to attract participants from a range of areas.

por.por_cntn:
This project considered the engineering aspects of how information is conveyed via timing, such as a pregnant pause when speaking or a delay in replying to an email. Neurons actually communicate with one another entirely via the timing of pulses, and the timing of events in computer and communication systems is a known mechanism by which sensitive information is leaked to eavesdroppers.

This project considered both methods for maximizing the information transmission via the timing of events---which is relevant to understanding how the brain works---and methods for minimizing the inevitable flow of information through the timing of events---which is relevant to computer and communications security. The project developed various mathematical tools for analyzing and designing systems that convey information via the timing of events.

One of the main contributions of the project was a new metric for measuring leakage in systems in which an eavesdropper is present. Many systems inevitably and unavoidably leak information to passive observers --- a smart electric meter that reports real-time power consumption in a house inevitably leaks some amount of information to the power company about the activities inside that house. Prior to this project, there was no cogently justified quantitative metric for meauring information leakage in these contexts. Thus, engineers were forced to rely on approximate metrics or qualitative approaches. This project provided a well-justified, quantitative metric that can be easily computed in real-world examples and used to guide engineering designs in a way that minimize undesirable leakage. The ultimate broader impact of the work thus includes the design of privacy-preserving infrastructure. This project also contributed to the diversification of the research and engineering workforce by enabling the PI to support female Ph.D. students.
